summary.long: Exodus is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each with his household:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the descendants of Jacob were seventy persons; Joseph was already in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph died, and all his brothers and all that generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Israel were fruitful and increased greatly; they multiplied and grew exceedingly strong, so that the land was filled with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there arose a new king over Egypt, who did not know Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said to his people, “Behold, the people of Israel are too many and too mighty for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let us deal shrewdly with them, lest they multiply, and, if war breaks out, they join our enemies and fight against us and escape from the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore they set taskmasters over them to afflict them with heavy burdens. They built for Pharaoh store cities, Pithom and Raamses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and the more they spread abroad. And the Egyptians were in dread of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they ruthlessly made the people of Israel work as slaves
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and made their lives bitter with hard service, in mortar and brick, and in all kinds of work in the field. In all their work they ruthlessly made them work as slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you serve as midwife to the Hebrew women and see them on the birthstool, if it is a son, you shall kill him, but if it is a daughter, she shall live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the midwives feared God and did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but let the male children live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Egypt called the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this, and let the male children live?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women, for they are vigorous and give birth before the midwife comes to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God dealt well with the midwives. And the people multiplied and grew very strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people, “Every son that is born to the Hebrews you shall cast into the Nile, but you shall let every daughter live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a man from the house of Levi went and took as his wife a Levite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman conceived and bore a son, and when she saw that he was a fine child, she hid him for three months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she could hide him no longer, she took for him a basket made of bulrushes and daubed it with bitumen and pitch. She put the child in it and placed it among the reeds by the river bank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And his sister stood at a distance to know what would be done to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the daughter of Pharaoh came down to bathe at the river, while her young women walked beside the river. She saw the basket among the reeds and sent her servant woman, and she took it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she opened it, she saw the child, and behold, the baby was crying. She took pity on him and said, “This is one of the Hebrews' children.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh's daughter, “Shall I go and call you a nurse from the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh's daughter said to her, “Go.” So the girl went and called the child's mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh's daughter said to her, “Take this child away and nurse him for me, and I will give you your wages.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the child grew up, she brought him to Pharaoh's daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, “Because,” she said, “I drew him out of the water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day, when Moses had grown up, he went out to his people and looked on their burdens, and he saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked this way and that, and seeing no one, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he went out the next day, behold, two Hebrews were struggling together. And he said to the man in the wrong, “Why do you strike your companion?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “Who made you a prince and a judge over us? Do you mean to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid, and thought, “Surely the thing is known.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh heard of it, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from Pharaoh and stayed in the land of Midian. And he sat down by a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came and drew water and filled the troughs to water their father's flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The shepherds came and drove them away, but Moses stood up and saved them, and watered their flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came home to their father Reuel, he said, “How is it that you have come home so soon today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the shepherds and even drew water for us and watered the flock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his daughters, “Then where is he? Why have you left the man? Call him, that he may eat bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses was content to dwell with the man, and he gave Moses his daughter Zipporah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave birth to a son, and he called his name Gershom, for he said, “I have been a sojourner in a foreign land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During those many days the king of Egypt died, and the people of Israel groaned because of their slavery and cried out for help. Their cry for rescue from slavery came up to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God saw the people of Israel—and God knew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses was keeping the flock of his father-in-law, Jethro, the priest of Midian, and he led his flock to the west side of the wilderness and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the angel of the Lord appeared to him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush. He looked, and behold, the bush was burning, yet it was not consumed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said, “I will turn aside to see this great sight, why the bush is not burned.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord saw that he turned aside to see, God called to him out of the bush, “Moses, Moses!” And he said, “Here I am.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then he said, “Do not come near; take your sandals off your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And he said, “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” And Moses hid his face, for he was afraid to look at God.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then the Lord said, “I have surely seen the affliction of my people who are in Egypt and have heard their cry because of their taskmasters. I know their sufferings,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: and I have come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land to a good and broad land, a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And now, behold, the cry of the people of Israel has come to me, and I have also seen the oppression with which the Egyptians oppress them.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Come, I will send you to Pharaoh that you may bring my people, the children of Israel, out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the children of Israel out of Egypt?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: He said, “But I will be with you, and this shall be the sign for you, that I have sent you: when you have brought the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then Moses said to God, “If I come to the people of Israel and say to them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you’, and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’ what shall I say to them?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God said to Moses, “I am who I am.” And he said, “Say this to the people of Israel, ‘I am has sent me to you.’”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God also said to Moses, “Say this to the people of Israel, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.’ This is my name for ever, and thus I am to be remembered throughout all generations.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Go and gather the elders of Israel together and say to them, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, has appeared to me, saying, “I have observed you and what has been done to you in Egypt,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: and I promise that I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt to the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, a land flowing with milk and honey.”’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And they will listen to your voice, and you and the elders of Israel shall go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us; and now, please let us go a three days' journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go unless compelled by a mighty hand.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I will stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all the wonders that I will do in it; after that he will let you go.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And I will give this people favour in the sight of the Egyptians; and when you go, you shall not go empty,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: but each woman shall ask of her neighbour, and any woman who lives in her house, for silver and gold jewellery, and for clothing. You shall put them on your sons and on your daughters. So you shall plunder the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then Moses answered, “But behold, they will not believe me or listen to my voice, for they will say, ‘The Lord did not appear to you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” He said, “A staff.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said, “Throw it on the ground.” So he threw it on the ground, and it became a serpent, and Moses ran from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand and catch it by the tail”—so he put out his hand and caught it, and it became a staff in his hand—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again, the Lord said to him, “Put your hand inside your cloak.” And he put his hand inside his cloak, and when he took it out, behold, his hand was leprous like snow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said, “Put your hand back inside your cloak.” So he put his hand back inside his cloak, and when he took it out, behold, it was restored like the rest of his flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If they will not believe you,” God said, “or listen to the first sign, they may believe the latter sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they will not believe even these two signs or listen to your voice, you shall take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground, and the water that you shall take from the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Oh, my Lord, I am not eloquent, either in the past or since you have spoken to your servant, but I am slow of speech and of tongue.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to him, “Who has made man's mouth? Who makes him mute, or deaf, or seeing, or blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore go, and I will be with your mouth and teach you what you shall speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “Oh, my Lord, please send someone else.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses and he said, “Is there not Aaron, your brother, the Levite? I know that he can speak well. Behold, he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you, he will be glad in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall speak to him and put the words in his mouth, and I will be with your mouth and with his mouth and will teach you both what to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He shall speak for you to the people, and he shall be your mouth, and you shall be as God to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And take in your hand this staff, with which you shall do the signs.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, “Please let me go back to my brothers in Egypt to see whether they are still alive.” And Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, for all the men who were seeking your life are dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and his sons and put them on a donkey, and went back to the land of Egypt. And Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, see that you do before Pharaoh all the miracles that I have put in your power. But I will harden his heart, so that he will not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you shall say to Pharaoh, ‘Thus says the Lord, Israel is my firstborn son,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I say to you, “Let my son go that he may serve me.” If you refuse to let him go, behold, I will kill your firstborn son.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At a lodging place on the way the Lord met him and sought to put him to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son's foreskin and touched Moses' feet with it and said, “Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he let him alone. It was then that she said, “A bridegroom of blood”, because of the circumcision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Aaron, “Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.” So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which he had sent him to speak, and all the signs that he had commanded him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron spoke all the words that the Lord had spoken to Moses and did the signs in the sight of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people believed; and when they heard that the Lord had visited the people of Israel and that he had seen their affliction, they bowed their heads and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards Moses and Aaron went and said to Pharaoh, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, ‘Let my people go, that they may hold a feast to me in the wilderness.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord, that I should obey his voice and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and moreover, I will not let Israel go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us go a three days' journey into the wilderness that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God, lest he fall upon us with pestilence or with the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why do you take the people away from their work? Get back to your burdens.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh said, “Behold, the people of the land are now many, and you make them rest from their burdens!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The same day Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters of the people and their foremen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You shall no longer give the people straw to make bricks, as in the past; let them go and gather straw for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the number of bricks that they made in the past you shall impose on them, you shall by no means reduce it, for they are idle. Therefore they cry, ‘Let us go and offer sacrifice to our God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let heavier work be laid on the men that they may labour at it and pay no regard to lying words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the taskmasters and the foremen of the people went out and said to the people, “Thus says Pharaoh, ‘I will not give you straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go and get your straw yourselves wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced in the least.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people were scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The taskmasters were urgent, saying, “Complete your work, your daily task each day, as when there was straw.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the foremen of the people of Israel, whom Pharaoh's taskmasters had set over them, were beaten and were asked, “Why have you not done all your task of making bricks today and yesterday, as in the past?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the foremen of the people of Israel came and cried to Pharaoh, “Why do you treat your servants like this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No straw is given to your servants, yet they say to us, ‘Make bricks!’ And behold, your servants are beaten; but the fault is in your own people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “You are idle, you are idle; that is why you say, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go now and work. No straw will be given you, but you must still deliver the same number of bricks.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foremen of the people of Israel saw that they were in trouble when they said, “You shall by no means reduce your number of bricks, your daily task each day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They met Moses and Aaron, who were waiting for them, as they came out from Pharaoh;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they said to them, “The Lord look on you and judge, because you have made us stink in the sight of Pharaoh and his servants, and have put a sword in their hand to kill us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses turned to the Lord and said, “O Lord, why have you done evil to this people? Why did you ever send me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has done evil to this people, and you have not delivered your people at all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Now you shall see what I will do to Pharaoh; for with a strong hand he will send them out, and with a strong hand he will drive them out of his land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God spoke to Moses and said to him, “I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, as God Almighty, but by my name the Lord I did not make myself known to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, the land in which they lived as sojourners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, I have heard the groaning of the people of Israel whom the Egyptians hold as slaves, and I have remembered my covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say therefore to the people of Israel, ‘I am the Lord, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will deliver you from slavery to them, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great acts of judgement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take you to be my people, and I will be your God, and you shall know that I am the Lord your God, who has brought you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring you into the land that I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob. I will give it to you for a possession. I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses spoke thus to the people of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses, because of their broken spirit and harsh slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go in, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the people of Israel go out of his land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Behold, the people of Israel have not listened to me. How then shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and gave them a charge about the people of Israel and about Pharaoh king of Egypt: to bring the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the heads of their fathers' houses: the sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi; these are the clans of Reuben.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman; these are the clans of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari, the years of the life of Levi being 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gershon: Libni and Shimei, by their clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel, the years of the life of Kohath being 133 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of the Levites according to their generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amram took as his wife Jochebed his father's sister, and she bore him Aaron and Moses, the years of the life of Amram being 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron took as his wife Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab and the sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph; these are the clans of the Korahites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eleazar, Aaron's son, took as his wife one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the fathers' houses of the Levites by their clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said: “Bring out the people of Israel from the land of Egypt by their hosts.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was they who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing out the people of Israel from Egypt, this Moses and this Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day when the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord said to Moses, “I am the Lord; tell Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Behold, I am of uncircumcised lips. How will Pharaoh listen to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron shall be your prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall speak all that I command you, and your brother Aaron shall tell Pharaoh to let the people of Israel go out of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and though I multiply my signs and wonders in the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh will not listen to you. Then I will lay my hand on Egypt and bring my hosts, my people the children of Israel, out of the land of Egypt by great acts of judgement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring out the people of Israel from among them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did so; they did just as the Lord commanded them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses was eighty years old, and Aaron eighty-three years old, when they spoke to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Prove yourselves by working a miracle’, then you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and cast it down before Pharaoh, that it may become a serpent.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did just as the Lord commanded. Aaron cast down his staff before Pharaoh and his servants, and it became a serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned the wise men and the sorcerers, and they, the magicians of Egypt, also did the same by their secret arts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For each man cast down his staff, and they became serpents. But Aaron's staff swallowed up their staffs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Still Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh's heart is hardened; he refuses to let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning, as he is going out to the water. Stand on the bank of the Nile to meet him, and take in your hand the staff that turned into a serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you shall say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, sent me to you, saying, “Let my people go, that they may serve me in the wilderness. But so far, you have not obeyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus says the Lord, “By this you shall know that I am the Lord: behold, with the staff that is in my hand I will strike the water that is in the Nile, and it shall turn into blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish in the Nile shall die, and the Nile will stink, and the Egyptians will grow weary of drinking water from the Nile.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt, over their rivers, their canals, and their ponds, and all their pools of water, so that they may become blood, and there shall be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, even in vessels of wood and in vessels of stone.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did as the Lord commanded. In the sight of Pharaoh and in the sight of his servants he lifted up the staff and struck the water in the Nile, and all the water in the Nile turned into blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the fish in the Nile died, and the Nile stank, so that the Egyptians could not drink water from the Nile. There was blood throughout all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians of Egypt did the same by their secret arts. So Pharaoh's heart remained hardened, and he would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh turned and went into his house, and he did not take even this to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the Egyptians dug along the Nile for water to drink, for they could not drink the water of the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven full days passed after the Lord had struck the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go in to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘Thus says the Lord, “Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to let them go, behold, I will plague all your country with frogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nile shall swarm with frogs that shall come up into your house and into your bedroom and on your bed and into the houses of your servants and your people, and into your ovens and your kneading bowls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs shall come up on you and on your people and on all your servants.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, over the canals and over the pools, and make frogs come up on the land of Egypt!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians did the same by their secret arts and made frogs come up on the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, “Plead with the Lord to take away the frogs from me and from my people, and I will let the people go to sacrifice to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “Be pleased to command me when I am to plead for you and for your servants and for your people, that the frogs be cut off from you and your houses and be left only in the Nile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said, “Tomorrow.” Moses said, “Be it as you say, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs shall go away from you and your houses and your servants and your people. They shall be left only in the Nile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried to the Lord about the frogs, as he had agreed with Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord did according to the word of Moses. The frogs died out in the houses, the courtyards, and the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they gathered them together in heaps, and the land stank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was a respite, he hardened his heart and would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the earth, so that it may become gnats in all the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they did so. Aaron stretched out his hand with his staff and struck the dust of the earth, and there were gnats on man and beast. All the dust of the earth became gnats in all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians tried by their secret arts to produce gnats, but they could not. So there were gnats on man and beast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the magicians said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Rise up early in the morning and present yourself to Pharaoh, as he goes out to the water, and say to him, ‘Thus says the Lord, “Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Or else, if you will not let my people go, behold, I will send swarms of flies on you and your servants and your people, and into your houses. And the houses of the Egyptians shall be filled with swarms of flies, and also the ground on which they stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But on that day I will set apart the land of Goshen, where my people dwell, so that no swarms of flies shall be there, that you may know that I am the Lord in the midst of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus I will put a division between my people and your people. Tomorrow this sign shall happen.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord did so. There came great swarms of flies into the house of Pharaoh and into his servants' houses. Throughout all the land of Egypt the land was ruined by the swarms of flies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, sacrifice to your God within the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, “It would not be right to do so, for the offerings we shall sacrifice to the Lord our God are an abomination to the Egyptians. If we sacrifice offerings abominable to the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We must go three days' journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God as he tells us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh said, “I will let you go to sacrifice to the Lord your God in the wilderness; only you must not go very far away. Plead for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said, “Behold, I am going out from you and I will plead with the Lord that the swarms of flies may depart from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people, tomorrow. Only let not Pharaoh cheat again by not letting the people go to sacrifice to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord did as Moses asked, and removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people; not one remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also, and did not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go in to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘Thus says the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, “Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if you refuse to let them go and still hold them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: behold, the hand of the Lord will fall with a very severe plague upon your livestock that are in the field, the horses, the donkeys, the camels, the herds, and the flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, so that nothing of all that belongs to the people of Israel shall die.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord set a time, saying, “Tomorrow the Lord will do this thing in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the next day the Lord did this thing. All the livestock of the Egyptians died, but not one of the livestock of the people of Israel died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh sent, and behold, not one of the livestock of Israel was dead. But the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, and he did not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from the kiln, and let Moses throw them in the air in the sight of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall become fine dust over all the land of Egypt, and become boils breaking out in sores on man and beast throughout all the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took soot from the kiln and stood before Pharaoh. And Moses threw it in the air, and it became boils breaking out in sores on man and beast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for the boils came upon the magicians and upon all the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and he did not listen to them, as the Lord had spoken to Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Rise up early in the morning and present yourself before Pharaoh and say to him, ‘Thus says the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, “Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this time I will send all my plagues on you yourself, and on your servants and your people, so that you may know that there is none like me in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For by now I could have put out my hand and struck you and your people with pestilence, and you would have been cut off from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But for this purpose I have raised you up, to show you my power, so that my name may be proclaimed in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are still exalting yourself against my people and will not let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, about this time tomorrow I will cause very heavy hail to fall, such as never has been in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore send, get your livestock and all that you have in the field into safe shelter, for every man and beast that is in the field and is not brought home will die when the hail falls on them.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then whoever feared the word of the Lord among the servants of Pharaoh hurried his slaves and his livestock into the houses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but whoever did not pay attention to the word of the Lord left his slaves and his livestock in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand towards heaven, so that there may be hail in all the land of Egypt, on man and beast and every plant of the field, in the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his staff towards heaven, and the Lord sent thunder and hail, and fire ran down to the earth. And the Lord rained hail upon the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was hail and fire flashing continually in the midst of the hail, very heavy hail, such as had never been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hail struck down everything that was in the field in all the land of Egypt, both man and beast. And the hail struck down every plant of the field and broke every tree of the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the people of Israel were, was there no hail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent and called Moses and Aaron and said to them, “This time I have sinned; the Lord is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Plead with the Lord, for there has been enough of God's thunder and hail. I will let you go, and you shall stay no longer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to him, “As soon as I have gone out of the city, I will stretch out my hands to the Lord. The thunder will cease, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know that the earth is the Lord's.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you and your servants, I know that you do not yet fear the Lord God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The flax and the barley were struck down, for the barley was in the ear and the flax was in bud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the wheat and the emmer were not struck down, for they are late in coming up.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went out of the city from Pharaoh and stretched out his hands to the Lord, and the thunder and the hail ceased, and the rain no longer poured upon the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain and the hail and the thunder had ceased, he sinned yet again and hardened his heart, he and his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, and he did not let the people of Israel go, just as the Lord had spoken through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go in to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants, that I may show these signs of mine among them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and that you may tell in the hearing of your son and of your grandson how I have dealt harshly with the Egyptians and what signs I have done among them, that you may know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went in to Pharaoh and said to him, “Thus says the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if you refuse to let my people go, behold, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your country,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they shall cover the face of the land, so that no one can see the land. And they shall eat what is left to you after the hail, and they shall eat every tree of yours that grows in the field,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they shall fill your houses and the houses of all your servants and of all the Egyptians, as neither your fathers nor your grandfathers have seen, from the day they came on earth to this day.’” Then he turned and went out from Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh's servants said to him, “How long shall this man be a snare to us? Let the men go, that they may serve the Lord their God. Do you not yet understand that Egypt is ruined?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. And he said to them, “Go, serve the Lord your God. But which ones are to go?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “We will go with our young and our old. We will go with our sons and daughters and with our flocks and herds, for we must hold a feast to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said to them, “The Lord be with you, if ever I let you and your little ones go! Look, you have some evil purpose in mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! Go, the men among you, and serve the Lord, for that is what you are asking.” And they were driven out from Pharaoh's presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts, so that they may come upon the land of Egypt and eat every plant in the land, all that the hail has left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his staff over the land of Egypt, and the Lord brought an east wind upon the land all that day and all that night. When it was morning, the east wind had brought the locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The locusts came up over all the land of Egypt and settled on the whole country of Egypt, such a dense swarm of locusts as had never been before, nor ever will be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They covered the face of the whole land, so that the land was darkened, and they ate all the plants in the land and all the fruit of the trees that the hail had left. Not a green thing remained, neither tree nor plant of the field, through all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh hastily called Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God, and against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, forgive my sin, please, only this once, and plead with the Lord your God only to remove this death from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he went out from Pharaoh and pleaded with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord turned the wind into a very strong west wind, which lifted the locusts and drove them into the Red Sea. Not a single locust was left in all the country of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not let the people of Israel go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand towards heaven, that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, a darkness to be felt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand towards heaven, and there was pitch darkness in all the land of Egypt for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did not see one another, nor did anyone rise from his place for three days, but all the people of Israel had light where they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and said, “Go, serve the Lord; your little ones also may go with you; only let your flocks and your herds remain behind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, “You must also let us have sacrifices and burnt offerings, that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our livestock also must go with us; not a hoof shall be left behind, for we must take of them to serve the Lord our God, and we do not know with what we must serve the Lord until we arrive there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he would not let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to him, “Get away from me; take care never to see my face again, for on the day you see my face you shall die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “As you say! I will not see your face again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Yet one plague more I will bring upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt. Afterwards he will let you go from here. When he lets you go, he will drive you away completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Speak now in the hearing of the people, that they ask, every man of his neighbour and every woman of her neighbour, for silver and gold jewellery.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord gave the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians. Moreover, the man Moses was very great in the land of Egypt, in the sight of Pharaoh's servants and in the sight of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses said, “Thus says the Lord: About midnight I will go out in the midst of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and every firstborn in the land of Egypt shall die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sits on his throne, even to the firstborn of the slave girl who is behind the handmill, and all the firstborn of the cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There shall be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt, such as there has never been, nor ever will be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But not a dog shall growl against any of the people of Israel, either man or beast, that you may know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all these your servants shall come down to me and bow down to me, saying, ‘Get out, you and all the people who follow you.’ And after that I will go out.” And he went out from Pharaoh in hot anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you, that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did all these wonders before Pharaoh, and the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not let the people of Israel go out of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This month shall be for you the beginning of months. It shall be the first month of the year for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell all the congregation of Israel that on the tenth day of this month every man shall take a lamb according to their fathers' houses, a lamb for a household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if the household is too small for a lamb, then he and his nearest neighbour shall take according to the number of persons; according to what each can eat you shall make your count for the lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your lamb shall be without blemish, a male a year old. You may take it from the sheep or from the goats,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you shall keep it until the fourteenth day of this month, when the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill their lambs at twilight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then they shall take some of the blood and put it on the two doorposts and the lintel of the houses in which they eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall eat the flesh that night, roasted on the fire; with unleavened bread and bitter herbs they shall eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not eat any of it raw or boiled in water, but roasted, its head with its legs and its inner parts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you shall let none of it remain until the morning; anything that remains until the morning you shall burn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this manner you shall eat it: with your belt fastened, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. And you shall eat it in haste. It is the Lord's Passover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I will pass through the land of Egypt that night, and I will strike all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both man and beast; and on all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgements: I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The blood shall be a sign for you, on the houses where you are. And when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and no plague will befall you to destroy you, when I strike the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This day shall be for you a memorial day, and you shall keep it as a feast to the Lord; throughout your generations, as a statute for ever, you shall keep it as a feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread. On the first day you shall remove leaven out of your houses, for if anyone eats what is leavened, from the first day until the seventh day, that person shall be cut off from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day you shall hold a holy assembly, and on the seventh day a holy assembly. No work shall be done on those days. But what everyone needs to eat, that alone may be prepared by you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you shall observe the Feast of Unleavened Bread, for on this very day I brought your hosts out of the land of Egypt. Therefore you shall observe this day, throughout your generations, as a statute for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month, from the fourteenth day of the month at evening, you shall eat unleavened bread until the twenty-first day of the month at evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days no leaven is to be found in your houses. If anyone eats what is leavened, that person will be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether he is a sojourner or a native of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall eat nothing leavened; in all your dwelling places you shall eat unleavened bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, “Go and select lambs for yourselves according to your clans, and kill the Passover lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take a bunch of hyssop and dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and touch the lintel and the two doorposts with the blood that is in the basin. None of you shall go out of the door of his house until the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord will pass through to strike the Egyptians, and when he sees the blood on the lintel and on the two doorposts, the Lord will pass over the door and will not allow the destroyer to enter your houses to strike you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall observe this rite as a statute for you and for your sons for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when you come to the land that the Lord will give you, as he has promised, you shall keep this service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when your children say to you, ‘What do you mean by this service?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you shall say, ‘It is the sacrifice of the Lord's Passover, for he passed over the houses of the people of Israel in Egypt, when he struck the Egyptians but spared our houses.’” And the people bowed their heads and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel went and did so; as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron, so they did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At midnight the Lord struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sat on his throne to the firstborn of the captive who was in the dungeon, and all the firstborn of the livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh rose up in the night, he and all his servants and all the Egyptians. And there was a great cry in Egypt, for there was not a house where someone was not dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he summoned Moses and Aaron by night and said, “Up, go out from among my people, both you and the people of Israel; and go, serve the Lord, as you have said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take your flocks and your herds, as you have said, and be gone, and bless me also!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians were urgent with the people to send them out of the land in haste. For they said, “We shall all be dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people took their dough before it was leavened, their kneading bowls being bound up in their cloaks on their shoulders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel had also done as Moses told them, for they had asked the Egyptians for silver and gold jewellery and for clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord had given the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they let them have what they asked. Thus they plundered the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides women and children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A mixed multitude also went up with them, and very much livestock, both flocks and herds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they baked unleavened cakes of the dough that they had brought out of Egypt, for it was not leavened, because they were thrust out of Egypt and could not wait, nor had they prepared any provisions for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time that the people of Israel lived in Egypt was 430 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of 430 years, on that very day, all the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was a night of watching by the Lord, to bring them out of the land of Egypt; so this same night is a night of watching kept to the Lord by all the people of Israel throughout their generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “This is the statute of the Passover: no foreigner shall eat of it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but every slave that is bought for money may eat of it after you have circumcised him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No foreigner or hired servant may eat of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall be eaten in one house; you shall not take any of the flesh outside the house, and you shall not break any of its bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the congregation of Israel shall keep it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a stranger shall sojourn with you and would keep the Passover to the Lord, let all his males be circumcised. Then he may come near and keep it; he shall be as a native of the land. But no uncircumcised person shall eat of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There shall be one law for the native and for the stranger who sojourns among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Israel did just as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on that very day the Lord brought the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their hosts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Consecrate to me all the firstborn. Whatever is the first to open the womb among the people of Israel, both of man and of beast, is mine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to the people, “Remember this day in which you came out from Egypt, out of the house of slavery, for by a strong hand the Lord brought you out from this place. No leavened bread shall be eaten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today, in the month of Abib, you are going out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which he swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey, you shall keep this service in this month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day there shall be a feast to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Unleavened bread shall be eaten for seven days; no leavened bread shall be seen with you, and no leaven shall be seen with you in all your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall tell your son on that day, ‘It is because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it shall be to you as a sign on your hand and as a memorial between your eyes, that the law of the Lord may be in your mouth. For with a strong hand the Lord has brought you out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall therefore keep this statute at its appointed time from year to year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites, as he swore to you and your fathers, and shall give it to you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you shall set apart to the Lord all that first opens the womb. All the firstborn of your animals that are males shall be the Lord's.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb, or if you will not redeem it you shall break its neck. Every firstborn of man among your sons you shall redeem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when in time to come your son asks you, ‘What does this mean?’ you shall say to him, ‘By a strong hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt, from the house of slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the Lord killed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both the firstborn of man and the firstborn of animals. Therefore I sacrifice to the Lord all the males that first open the womb, but all the firstborn of my sons I redeem.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall be as a mark on your hand or frontlets between your eyes, for by a strong hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them by way of the land of the Philistines, although that was near. For God said, “Lest the people change their minds when they see war and return to Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God led the people round by the way of the wilderness towards the Red Sea. And the people of Israel went up out of the land of Egypt equipped for battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for Joseph had made the sons of Israel solemnly swear, saying, “God will surely visit you, and you shall carry up my bones with you from here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they moved on from Succoth and encamped at Etham, on the edge of the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord went before them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, that they might travel by day and by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night did not depart from before the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the people of Israel to turn back and encamp in front of Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, in front of Baal-zephon; you shall encamp facing it, by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Pharaoh will say of the people of Israel, ‘They are wandering in the land; the wilderness has shut them in.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and he will pursue them, and I will get glory over Pharaoh and all his host, and the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord.” And they did so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, the mind of Pharaoh and his servants was changed towards the people, and they said, “What is this we have done, that we have let Israel go from serving us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he made ready his chariot and took his army with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and took six hundred chosen chariots and all the other chariots of Egypt with officers over all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he pursued the people of Israel while the people of Israel were going out defiantly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them, all Pharaoh's horses and chariots and his horsemen and his army, and overtook them encamped at the sea, by Pi-hahiroth, in front of Baal-zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh drew near, the people of Israel lifted up their eyes, and behold, the Egyptians were marching after them, and they feared greatly. And the people of Israel cried out to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Moses, “Is it because there are no graves in Egypt that you have taken us away to die in the wilderness? What have you done to us in bringing us out of Egypt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is not this what we said to you in Egypt: ‘Leave us alone that we may serve the Egyptians’? For it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said to the people, “Fear not, stand firm, and see the salvation of the Lord, which he will work for you today. For the Egyptians whom you see today, you shall never see again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will fight for you, and you have only to be silent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Why do you cry to me? Tell the people of Israel to go forward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lift up your staff, and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it, that the people of Israel may go through the sea on dry ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they shall go in after them, and I will get glory over Pharaoh and all his host, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I have gained glory over Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of God who was going before the host of Israel moved and went behind them, and the pillar of cloud moved from before them and stood behind them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: coming between the host of Egypt and the host of Israel. And there was the cloud and the darkness. And it lit up the night without one coming near the other all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the Lord drove the sea back by a strong east wind all night and made the sea dry land, and the waters were divided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people of Israel went into the midst of the sea on dry ground, the waters being a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued and went in after them into the midst of the sea, all Pharaoh's horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And in the morning watch the Lord in the pillar of fire and of cloud looked down on the Egyptian forces and threw the Egyptian forces into a panic,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: clogging their chariot wheels so that they drove heavily. And the Egyptians said, “Let us flee from before Israel, for the Lord fights for them against the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea, that the water may come back upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots, and upon their horsemen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to its normal course when the morning appeared. And as the Egyptians fled into it, the Lord threw the Egyptians into the midst of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters returned and covered the chariots and the horsemen; of all the host of Pharaoh that had followed them into the sea, not one of them remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Israel walked on dry ground through the sea, the waters being a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus the Lord saved Israel that day from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel saw the great power that the Lord used against the Egyptians, so the people feared the Lord, and they believed in the Lord and in his servant Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is my strength and my song,
    and he has become my salvation;
this is my God, and I will praise him,
    my father's God, and I will exalt him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is a man of war;
    the Lord is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Pharaoh's chariots and his host he cast into the sea,
    and his chosen officers were sunk in the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The floods covered them;
    they went down into the depths like a stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your right hand, O Lord, glorious in power,
    your right hand, O Lord, shatters the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the greatness of your majesty you overthrow your adversaries;
    you send out your fury; it consumes them like stubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The enemy said, ‘I will pursue, I will overtake,
    I will divide the spoil, my desire shall have its fill of them.
    I will draw my sword; my hand shall destroy them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You blew with your wind; the sea covered them;
    they sank like lead in the mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is like you, O Lord, among the gods?
    Who is like you, majestic in holiness,
    awesome in glorious deeds, doing wonders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You stretched out your right hand;
    the earth swallowed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You have led in your steadfast love the people whom you have redeemed;
    you have guided them by your strength to your holy abode.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The peoples have heard; they tremble;
    pangs have seized the inhabitants of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Terror and dread fall upon them;
    because of the greatness of your arm, they are still as a stone,
till your people, O Lord, pass by,
    till the people pass by whom you have purchased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will bring them in and plant them on your own mountain,
    the place, O Lord, which you have made for your abode,
    the sanctuary, O Lord, which your hands have established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will reign for ever and ever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when the horses of Pharaoh with his chariots and his horsemen went into the sea, the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them, but the people of Israel walked on dry ground in the midst of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and dancing.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses made Israel set out from the Red Sea, and they went into the wilderness of Shur. They went three days in the wilderness and found no water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the water of Marah because it was bitter; therefore it was named Marah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people grumbled against Moses, saying, “What shall we drink?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he cried to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a log, and he threw it into the water, and the water became sweet.
There the Lord made for them a statute and a rule, and there he tested them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, “If you will diligently listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and do that which is right in his eyes, and give ear to his commandments and keep all his statutes, I will put none of the diseases on you that I put on the Egyptians, for I am the Lord, your healer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they encamped there by the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set out from Elim, and all the congregation of the people of Israel came to the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had departed from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the whole congregation of the people of Israel grumbled against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the people of Israel said to them, “Would that we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the meat pots and ate bread to the full, for you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this whole assembly with hunger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Behold, I am about to rain bread from heaven for you, and the people shall go out and gather a day's portion every day, that I may test them, whether they will walk in my law or not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day, when they prepare what they bring in, it will be twice as much as they gather daily.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the people of Israel, “At evening you shall know that it was the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in the morning you shall see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard your grumbling against the Lord. For what are we, that you grumble against us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said, “When the Lord gives you in the evening meat to eat and in the morning bread to the full, because the Lord has heard your grumbling that you grumble against him—what are we? Your grumbling is not against us but against the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Say to the whole congregation of the people of Israel, ‘Come near before the Lord, for he has heard your grumbling.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as soon as Aaron spoke to the whole congregation of the people of Israel, they looked towards the wilderness, and behold, the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have heard the grumbling of the people of Israel. Say to them, ‘At twilight you shall eat meat, and in the morning you shall be filled with bread. Then you shall know that I am the Lord your God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the evening quail came up and covered the camp, and in the morning dew lay around the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the dew had gone up, there was on the face of the wilderness a fine, flake-like thing, fine as frost on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, “It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Gather of it, each one of you, as much as he can eat. You shall each take an omer, according to the number of the persons that each of you has in his tent.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people of Israel did so. They gathered, some more, some less.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they measured it with an omer, whoever gathered much had nothing left over, and whoever gathered little had no lack. Each of them gathered as much as he could eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said to them, “Let no one leave any of it over till the morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they did not listen to Moses. Some left part of it till the morning, and it bred worms and stank. And Moses was angry with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Morning by morning they gathered it, each as much as he could eat; but when the sun grew hot, it melted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two omers each. And when all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said to them, “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Tomorrow is a day of solemn rest, a holy Sabbath to the Lord; bake what you will bake and boil what you will boil, and all that is left over lay aside to be kept till the morning.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they laid it aside till the morning, as Moses commanded them, and it did not stink, and there were no worms in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Eat it today, for today is a Sabbath to the Lord; today you will not find it in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, which is a Sabbath, there will be none.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day some of the people went out to gather, but they found none.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “How long will you refuse to keep my commandments and my laws?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See! The Lord has given you the Sabbath; therefore on the sixth day he gives you bread for two days. Remain each of you in his place; let no one go out of his place on the seventh day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the house of Israel called its name manna. It was like coriander seed, white, and the taste of it was like wafers made with honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Let an omer of it be kept throughout your generations, so that they may see the bread with which I fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar, and put an omer of manna in it, and place it before the Lord to be kept throughout your generations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it before the testimony to be kept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel ate the manna for forty years, till they came to a habitable land. They ate the manna till they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (An omer is the tenth part of an ephah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the congregation of the people of Israel moved on from the wilderness of Sin by stages, according to the commandment of the Lord, and camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the people quarrelled with Moses and said, “Give us water to drink.” And Moses said to them, “Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you test the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people thirsted there for water, and the people grumbled against Moses and said, “Why did you bring us up out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and our livestock with thirst?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses cried to the Lord, “What shall I do with this people? They are almost ready to stone me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Pass on before the people, taking with you some of the elders of Israel, and take in your hand the staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, I will stand before you there on the rock at Horeb, and you shall strike the rock, and water shall come out of it, and the people will drink.” And Moses did so, in the sight of the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
